ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I learned how to read Arabic faster, spell basic Arabic words and construct sentences. I was introduced to the basics of Arabic grammar as well.
Sarab was by far the best language professor I have ever had. I went from not knowing a thing about arabic to being able to write basic essays in the language in a little under a semester.
The basics of the Arabic language and Arab culture.
I developed speaking, writing and comprehension skills in arabic.
I learned how to write arabic script, read arabic, and speak the language at an elementary level. Further, I have a basic understanding to be able to listen to the language.
I gained the ability to communicate basic information about myself and others in my native language.
This course greatly developed my time management skills and really helped me learn what study methods are effective for language study.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
Strengths:
Lots of speaking practice

Weakness:
moved too quickly at some points 
vocabulary we learned wasn't really applicable to day-to-day speaking
There truly are no weaknesses with this course, it was very effective and can hardly be improved upon.

Strength: Sarab is an amazing teacher
Weakness: we lost access to Alif Baa in Lingco, so we were not able to go back and review vocab from the beginning of the semester
The teacher was one of the biggest strengths of the course. It was taught in a way that was easy to learn.

This course was very good at providing consistent learning of arabic. The course was very fast paced and it forced you to improve your understanding of the language at a quick level. This is also one of the weaknesses of the course. I found it a little too fast at times. It was so fast that there was almost no room for slacking. If you got behind, you got left behind in the class because there were absolutely no breaks.
Some of the LingCo work does not feel very suiting or useful. Final presentations were a great way to evaluate our ability to communicate without aid with information that is likely to occur.

I think that the main weakness of the class was the lack of heritage learner support. As a new Arabic learner, it was sometimes confusing to be around my classmates who had much more of a background in the language than I did.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes? It provides a good introduction to the language. I feel that it will be quite difficult for students who don't already know the Arabic alphabet as time wasn't really set aside to teach students that.
Yes, this course is probably one of the best in America to get someone to learn arabic.
Yes, it is challenging, but rewarding
Yes, I would recommend this course because I feel like I learned a lot.
Yes, usthatha sarab is very kind and is a phenomenal teacher. In my opinion, this course is the best way to start learning the language.
Yes! Teacher was outstandingly engaged and Arabic is a beautiful language that many benefit to have an understanding of and the culture along with it.

I would absolutely recommend this to another student who was willing to put in the work. It was challenging but incredibly rewarding. Professor Sarab is one of the best teachers I have ever hadmy main qualm is that I cannot continue to have her as my instructor.
